trial_type.Description: Class of the stimulus presented (a class is a set of stimuli with the same w_r and w_a values; there are eight phases per class, which all have distinct stim_file_index values but the same trial_type), corresponds to class_idx in the stimulus description csv. n/a indicates a digit-only trial, the sixteen seconds at the beginning and end of the run.

stim_file.Description: Name of the stimulus file, found within the /stimuli folder. n/a means no stimulus presented (in sixteen seconds at beginning and end of run).

stim_file_index.Description: Index (zero-indexed) of the presented stimulus in the corresponding stim_file. n/a means no stimulus presented (in the sixteen seconds at beginning and end of run).

response_time.Description: Response time measured in seconds. n/a denotes no button press (which is sometimes the correct response).

outcome.Description: Outcome of the trial, in signal detection theory terms. A stream of digits was presented at fixation, and the task was to press a button whenever a digit repeated. Correct response is to either press the button when digit repeats or to not press when digit changes.

Levels.n/a: In addition to subject responses, tsv contains info about presented stimuli. The stimuli changed every half second, whereas the digit changed every second, so n/a marks those inter-trial intervals.

note.Description: Space for extra info, this is used to identify those stimuli that correspond to blank trials (used when constructing GLMdenoise design matrix)

Levels.n/a: This was a regular stimulus or in the sixteen seconds at beginning and end of run.
Levels.blank trial: This was a blank stimulus (i.e., just a midgray screen)
